I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Mongolia has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide technical assistance (TA) for capacity development in urban transport. During the fact-
finding mission in July 2012, ADB and the government reached an understanding on the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference for consulting services for the Ulaanbaatar Urban Transport Capacity Development 
TA. The TA is in line with the ADB country operations business plan, 2012–2014 for Mongolia.1 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Challenges in Ulaanbaatar Urban Transport 
2.  The need for sustainable urban transport in Ulaanbaatar is one of the most important 
development issues facing the country. The transition to a market economy since the 1990s and 
a series of severe winters have resulted in the migration of many low-income families from the 
countryside into the ger3 areas around Ulaanbaatar. The city’s population increased from about 
600,000 in 1989 to more than 1.17 million in 2010, representing 42% of the nation’s population 
(2.8 million). Given the limited employment opportunities in other parts of the country, migration 
to Ulaanbaatar is expected to continue and is estimated to reach 1.4 million in 2020 and 
1.7 million in 2030.4 
 
3.  Since 1998, the number of registered vehicles in Ulaanbaatar has increased more than 
four times.5 Unplanned urbanization and the increasing fleet of vehicles have overwhelmed the 
city’s transport system, contributing to congestion and poor air quality. Poor traffic management, 
insufficient  parking  management  and  enforcement,  excessive  and  inappropriate  on-street 
parking  spaces,  lack  of  pedestrian  facilities,  poor  driver  discipline,  and  inadequate  traffic 
signaling and control exacerbate the traffic congestion. Increased travel time and frequency, 
excessive fuel use, and health problems due to vehicle emissions are reducing the quality of life 
in Ulaanbaatar. 
 
4.  Despite the rapid increase in motor vehicles, most Ulaanbaatar residents rely on public 
transport or walking to move about the city. The congestion problem has reduced the quality 
and reliability of their travel in the city. With an uncontrolled interaction of pedestrians and 
vehicles, traffic accidents are common.6 Ulaanbaatar routinely accounts for over 70% of annual 
traffic  accidents  in  the  country.  An  incidence  of  75  deaths  per  100,000  vehicles  per  year 
highlights the need for continued improvements in urban road safety and better protection for 
pedestrians.7 
 
5.  Ulaanbaatar needs support to strengthen its capacity to improve and manage its urban 
transport  system.  This  includes  strengthening  capacity  for  preparing  and  coordinating

B.  Need for Capacity Development 
6.  The Municipal Government of Ulaanbaatar (MGU) is preparing a city master plan for 
developing the city’s infrastructure, including urban roads, public transport, transport services, 
and traffic management. In line with the city master plan, MGU established a road fund and bus 
improvement  fund  to  finance  road  network  construction,  maintenance  works,  and  bus 
replacement. However, MGU also faces gaps and limitations in its capacity to address urban 
transport  problems,  prepare  long-term  policy  directions,  generate  integrated  solutions  for 
different  subsectors  of  urban  transport  in  a  sustainable  and  efficient  way,  and  coordinate 
investments  by  different  international  development  partners  (ADB,  the  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development, the Export-Import Bank of Korea, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China, the Japan International Cooperation Agency, and the World Bank). 
 
7.  Alongside  MGU,  a  range  of  agencies  have  responsibilities  for  urban  transport  in 
Ulaanbaatar,  including the  Public  Transport  Department,  the  Road  Department,  the  Traffic 
Police,  the  Road  Department  of  the  Capital  City  Government  of  Ulaanbaatar,  the  Road 
Department of the Ministry of Transport, and transport-related nongovernment organizations. 
 
8.  MGU and the urban transport agencies need increased capacity for (i) development, 
implementation,  and  enforcement  of  urban  transport  policy  and  strategy;  (ii) long-term 
investment planning, capital budgeting, and financial management; (iii) design and management 
of urban transport projects financed by international development partners; and (iv) technical 
knowledge and skills in transport planning, traffic engineering, public transport, and traffic safety. 
 
9.  ADB has approved a multitranche financing facility for the Urban Transport Development 
Investment Program8 to support upgrading of Ulaanbaatar’s public transport system, including 
introducing a city-wide bus rapid transit network and traffic management system over the next 
6–9 years. This investment program will follow an integrated approach to urban transport-
related  investment  activities  in  the  city,  including  coordination  of  activities  financed  by 
international development partners as well as MGU’s. TA is needed to support associated 
capacity  development  for  planning,  implementing,  and  managing  the  program  and  related 
investment activities. The TA is closely aligned with the objectives of ADB’s country partnership 
strategy, 2012–2016 for Mongolia, which highlights the need to support the development of 
sustainable urban transport systems in Ulaanbaatar.9 
 
10.  Through the TA, MGU will prepare detailed implementation plans for the development of 
urban  transport  in  Ulaanbaatar  and  strengthen  implementation  capacity  in  various  urban 
transport subsectors. Initially, this will require a combination of policy analysis and consultations 
and training for decision-makers to support preparation of the implementation plans.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be improved capacity of Ulaanbaatar urban transport agencies 
for  planning  and  managing  urban transport  in  an  integrated  and sustainable  manner.  The 
outcome will be enhanced awareness and knowledge of sustainable urban transport planning 
and management among Ulaanbaatar urban transport agencies. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will provide an opportunity for improving coordination between urban transport 
related agencies through TA activities covering six components: (i) sustainable urban transport, 
(ii) transport planning and management, (iii) traffic safety and enforcement, (iv) public transport 
planning and management, (v) intelligent transport systems, and (vi) financial management and 
procurement. 
 
13.  The  TA  will  have  three  outputs:  (i)  a  diagnostic  report  on  the  Ulaanbaatar  urban 
transport situation, problems, issues, constraints and policy directions; (ii) training materials and 
guidelines  for  the  six  components  produced  and  trainings  provided;  and  (iii)  improvement 
measures for the six components..The outputs will be produced through in-house advisory 
activities, case studies and the collaborations of different agencies of MGU, the Traffic Police, 
the Road Department of the Capital City Government of Ulaanbaatar, the Road Department of 
the Ministry of Transport, and transport-related nongovernment organizations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  suitably  furnished  offices  with  utilities; 
telecommunications  access;  materials,  maps,  data,  and  documents  required  by  the  TA; 
counterpart professional and support staff; and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MGU  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  implementing  agencies  will  comprise  the 
departments  of  public  transport,  roads,  and  information  technology;  and  other  agencies 
responsible for urban transport in Ulaanbaatar: the project implementation unit for the ADB-
financed program, the public transport and road departments of the Capital City Government of 
Ulaanbaatar; the Traffic Police, and the Road Department of the Ministry of Transport. The TA 
will be implemented from November 2012 to November 2014. 
 
16.  The TA requires 17 person-months of international and 32 person-months of national 
consultant inputs for the TA components engaged through a firm or individual in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursement  of  the  TA  will  be  undertaken  in  line  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). TA equipment will be procured 
by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time) and turned over to MGU upon completion of the TA. The selection of the consulting 
firm will use quality- and cost-based selection with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The consulting

4  
firm will be required to submit a simplified technical proposal covering all aspects of the terms of 
reference. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The  TA  consulting  team  will  submit  periodic  progress  reports  as  applicable.  The 
consultants will conduct three workshops to present findings and recommendations and solicit 
feedback from key stakeholders. Senior officials from MGU and other relevant ministries and 
agencies will be closely consulted and involved during TA implementation and the review of the 
TA outputs. They will be invited to participate in the TA review workshops and discussions. ADB 
missions will monitor TA progress and performance. The ADB project team is expected to 
prepare  and  disseminate  working  papers  describing  key  findings,  recommendations,  and 
lessons from TA implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Ulaanbaatar Urban Transport Capacity Development, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Team Leader and Urban Transport Specialist (8 person-months) 
 
1.  The specialist will (i) have a bachelor’s degree or above in transport-related areas;  
(ii) have at least 15 years of project management experience in urban transport policy and 
planning, and at least 10 years of international working experience in the urban transport sector; 
(iii) have a successful track record in leading a team of experts for similar assignments in 
Mongolia or similar countries; (iv) be familiar with international best practices in sustainable 
transport, transport planning, and traffic engineering and management; and (v) be fluent in 
English. 
 
2.  As the team leader, the urban transport specialist will, based on the knowledge and the 
experience  of  previous  projects,  establish  the  working  arrangements  and  take  overall 
responsibility for team performance. As the team leader, with support from other international 
and national consultants, the specialist will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  provide the Municipal Government of Ulaanbaatar (MGU) (the executing agency); 
the Public Transport Department, the Road Department, and the Informational 
Technology (IT) department with guidance and expert advice; 
(ii)  oversee  and  coordinate  the  work  of  all  consultants  engaged,  manage  their 
performance, and initiate corrective actions, if necessary;  
(iii)  maintain a close linkage between the training provided through the consulting 
services and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Urban Transport Development 
Investment Program;1 and 
(iv)  help other consultants organizing workshops, training, and case studies. 
 
3.  As the urban transport specialist, the consultant will 
 
(i)  help  MGU  develop  urban  transport  sustainability  policies,  strategy,  and 
investment plan; 
(ii)  help MGU implement ADB’s Urban Transport Development Investment Program; 
(iii)  produce training materials and guidelines tailored for Ulaanbaatar city; and 
(iv)  provide advice to MGU on preparing, coordinating, and managing public relations, 
media campaigns, and related consultations; and publicity required to ensure 
support for the program from key agencies, stakeholders, politicians, and the 
general public. 
 
  2.  Traffic Safety Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
4.  The traffic safety specialist will (i) have a bachelor’s degree or above in transport or 
traffic safety related areas; (ii) have at least 20 years of project management experience in 
traffic safety policy and management, and at least 15 years of international working experience 
in traffic safety policy; (iii) have a successful track record in leading a team of experts for 
assignments of a similar nature in Mongolia or similar countries; (iv) be familiar with international 
best practices in traffic safety; and (v) be fluent in English.

5.  The consultant will 
(i)  help MGU establish national and local activities for the five pillars2 recommended

framework of the Government of Mongolia and MGU;  
(ii)  provide  training  to  MGU  and  other  traffic  management  authorities,  including 
traffic police, in up-to-date traffic management and safety techniques; 
(iii)  help MGU implement the program, and produce a public relations strategy and 
materials; and 
(iv)  produce training materials and guidelines for Ulaanbaatar city. 
 
3.  Public Transport (Bus Rapid Transit) Planning and Management (3 person-
months) 
 
6.  The public transport specialist will (i) have a bachelor’s degree or above in transport or 
public transport management related areas; (ii) have at least 15 years of project management 
experience in public transport policy, planning, and management; and have at least 15 years of 
international working experience in public transport sector and bus rapid transit (BRT) planning 
and design; (iii) have a successful track record in leading a team of experts for assignments of a 
similar nature in Mongolia or similar countries; (iv) be familiar with international best practices in 
public transport planning, design, and BRT; and (v) be fluent in English. 
 
7.  The public transport specialist will 
(i)  review  the  public  transport  management  of  the  city  and  provide  options  for 
reforming the public transport management structure; 
(ii)  help MGU implement BRT design, planning, and operation plans; 
(iii)  help MGU implement ADB’s Urban Transport Development Investment Program 
and produce a public relations strategy and material; and 
(iv)  produce training materials and guidelines tailored for Ulaanbaatar city. 
 
4.  Intelligent Transport Systems) (1 person-month) 
 
8.  The specialist will (i) have a bachelor’s degree or above in intelligent transport system 
(ITS) related areas; (ii) have at least 15 years of project management experience in ITS design 
and operation, and system integration area; and have at least 10 years of international working 
experience  in  ITS;  (iii)  have  a  successful  track  record  in  leading  a  team  of  experts  for 
assignments of a similar nature in Mongolia or similar countries; (iv) be familiar with international 
best practices in ITS; and (v) be fluent in English.  
 
9.  The consultant will 
(i)  help MGU improve the current ITS system; 
(ii)  help MGU utilize the collected data for daily traffic operation and planning; 
(iii)  provide  training  and  capacity  development  in  ITS  planning  and  operation 
including a bus management system, bus information system, and e-ticketing 
system; and 
(iv)  produce training material and guidelines tailored for Ulaanbaatar city.

and (iv) be fluent in English. 
 
21.  The consultant will 
(i)  assist the international consultant in helping MGU develop and implement an 
efficient and transparent procurement practice for the program; 
(ii)  assist the international consultant in providing training and capacity development 
in ADB procurement guidelines, documentation, and requirements; and 
(iii)  help MGU develop bidding documents and undertake bid evaluation and contract 
awards for the program. 
 
C.  Reporting and Guidelines 
 
1.  Reports 
(i)  Inception report: 2 weeks after the mobilization; 
(ii)  Progress reports: Every two months after the inception report; and 
(iii)  Final progress report: June 2014. 
 
2.  Guidelines for Six Components 
(i)  Draft guidelines: 4 weeks after the completion of each components; and 
(ii)  Final guidelines: 4 weeks after completion of draft guidelines.
